newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin pledges no rise in taxes, public spending.
newsitem.headline: Jospin pledges no rise in taxes, public spending.

text.p: French Socialist leader Lionel Jospin pledged on Monday that he would neither raise income taxes nor boost public spending if the party won power in next Sunday's parliamentary election runoff vote.
"Let us say very clearly there will be no rise in income taxes and no rise in public spending," Jospin told France 3 television.
Jospin's party scored an upset win over the ruling centre- right coalition in Sunday's first voting round.
The Socialists would combine "realistic necessity with a change in political direction to focus on the fight against unemployment," he said.
"All that is coherent with our approach to European policy," he said.

The Socialist party has said it is committed to a single European currency but will not impose austerity just to fulfil a strict interpretation of a Maastricht treaty ceiling limiting budget deficits to three percent of gross domestic product.
